item.description:
Medieval cities were home to very different types of people. Not only pious monks, humble scholars and trustworthy merchants, but also those mischievous, cunning and dishonest. In Slyville, a board game of bluff and deceit, you become one of the latter kind. As head of a guild operating in one of the world's major trade and cultural centers of the Middle Ages, you will be sending your trusted right-hand men to various districts of the city to find trade bargains, make deals, and provide the organization with more power and wealth — not always in a way that is completely legal, but for sure fun and entertaining!

In Slyville, the players become heads of guilds operating in an unnamed medieval city and send their trusted aides to do business and close shady deals. Each turn they have seven cards in their hands and must play four of them onto spaces on the district boards placed in the center of the table. By using their card actions, they bid to acquire goods in five types that can later be spent on deal tiles. If a player has collected the goods required by a chosen deal, they must play a deal card and spend the appropriate goods. Tiles are worth 2-4 points, and the player who gathers 10 triggers the endgame. After that, the rest of the players take their final turn and points are counted. The highest scorer wins and becomes the most influential guild master of the city.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Cradle of Civilization is a two games in one pack that allows players to determine the fate of the ancient near east. In one game civilizations rise while in the other players battle over whether the great Persian Empire will survive. Both games emphasize simplicity but not at the price being unrealistic.

From Sumeria to Persia is about the Bronze and Iron Age, when civilization was born and city states went from kingdoms and finally to large empires, culminating in the Persian Empire founded by Cyrus the Great. Players of History of the World will recognize the base mechanics whereby players randomly select civilizations from cards, although the player in last place has more power to decide which civilization they will play.

From Sumeria to Persia does offer players more options than previous games on the subject. Civilizations that survive can continue to expand in future turns. Random events create possibilities that defy history but were in the realm of possibility. The Minoans may have a brilliant military commander and the Egyptians could become a seafaring empire. There are also rules for constructing wonders, the placement of cities, and the general effects of the Bronze Age collapse. Lastly, the Persian Empire does appear.

Alexander vs. Darius: The Fall of the Persian Empire simulates Alexander III’s conquest of the great Persian Empire. Sometimes portrayed as a foregone conclusion, this game argues that Persia certainly had a chance to win if they had used different strategies or had some luck on the battlefield. Darius III need not have been Persia’s last king.

The heart of Alexander vs. Darius is a war weariness track, which moves down steadily for Alexander’s army. Historically, it did not reach zero until after his invasion of India, but a Persian battlefield victory could have changed that. The game also allows players to explore Memnon’s strategy of using Persian naval supremacy to raid Alexander’s rear as well as exploring the possibilities of the Spartan rebellion. Lastly, the Persians themselves must worry about legitimacy, and therefore must be active in resisting Alexander, or risk losing their grip on the throne.

—description from the publisher

name.value: Smash Up: World Tour – International Incident

item.description:
Come along on the Smash Up World Tour!

International Incident is the start of a year-long trip around the four corners of the world to visit some of the coolest heroes that different cultures have to offer! From the cold of Canada to the heat of Mexico and beyond, this first World Tour set adds awesome factions to your fight for the bases.

The Luchadores bring their high-flying, death-defying wrestling combinations to the fight, and the Mounties are at their strongest while they get their man and keep the Great White North safe! The Musketeers use their explosive action chains to gallantly defeat enemies, and the Sumo Wrestlers bulk up and throw their weight around, knocking their enemies away from the base.

World Tour: International Incident is compatible with all other Smash Up expansions!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: Smash Up: World Tour – Culture Shock

item.description:
Widget Ridge is a steampunk-themed deckbuilding game, traditionally for 2 players (solo mode and extra players supported).

The game follows traditional deckbuilding mechanics of starting with a terrible deck of cards, and improving it with purchases and deck-thinning abilities.

Players take turns generating Gold and making Spark, purchasing new inventions from the Marketplace of Ideas, and combining these in their Workshop to make larger, crazier machines. Players can invent things like a Clockwork-Powered Butter Gun with a Parachute, a Coal-Powered Mechanical Bison with a Grappling Hook, or a Solar-Powered Battle Corset with an Antenna. The game has over 1000 combinations in the initial release.

The basic win condition is to gather 100 Spark, but the game also includes Goal cards that can alter the rules and win condition for additional replay value. Players can choose to concentrate on the game itself, or engage the rich story environment. The game is designed for 2+ players, but will have solo rules in the box.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
From the Kickstarter Page:
"The game is an unlimited multi-player board game to build the highest building in Dubai. The winner is the player who has the tallest building at the end of game."

Players first lay out their 10 hexagonal base tiles one by one in Phase I.

In Phase II they place one of their wooden polyominoes onto each base tiles of their color.

In Phase III each player moves one of their polyominoes in a straight line onto another tile, forming a tower. These movements are only legal, if the pieces are set higher than they started their movement.

If a tower tumbles, all the towers belonging to the player are removed from the game, meaning bankruptcy for the player.

The player who own the last tower, wins the game!

name.value: Battle of the Twin Villages: Krinkelt-Rocherath

item.description:
Battle of the Twin Villages: Krinkelt-Rocherath is a natural follow-on to the successful Hurtgen Forest monster.

The Battle of Elsenborn Ridge was the only sector of the American front lines during the Battle of the Bulge where the Germans failed to advance.[1] The battle centered on the Elsenborn Ridge east of Elsenborn, Belgium in the Ardennes forest. West of Elsenborn Ridge, near the cities of Liège and Spa, Belgium, was a vast array of Allied supplies and the well-developed road network leading to the Meuse River and Antwerp. The Germans planned on using two key rollbahns or routes through the area to seize Antwerp and force a separate peace with the United States and Britain. Capturing Monschau and the nearby village of Höfen, and the twin villages of Rocherath-Krinkelt just east of Elsenborn Ridge, were key to the success of the German plans, and Hitler committed his best armored units and infantry troops to the area, including the 12th SS Panzer Division Hitlerjugend.

The green, untested troops of the 99th Infantry Division had been placed in the sector during mid-November because the Allies thought it was an area unlikely to see battle. Their soldiers were stretched thin over a 22-mile front, and all three regiments were on line, with no reserve. In early December, the 2nd Infantry Division was assigned to capture a vital crossroads marked by a customs house and a forester’s lodge named Wahlerscheid, at the southern tip of the Battle of Hürtgen Forest. They transitioned through the 99th division's lines and after a deadly, costly battle, capturing the crossroads. But the Germans counterattacked in what the Americans initially thought was a localized spoiling action, but was actually a leading element of the Battle of the Bulge. The 2nd ID consolidated their lines, pulling back into Hünningen, and then to the twin villages of Rocherath-Krinkelt, and finally at the dug-in positions held by the 99th ID at Elsenborn Ridge.

What you get in ATS Battle of the Twin Villages:

ALL the combat counters you need to play
New, large-hex winterized map for the historical battlefield
Color Battlefield Walkaround rules in 3-hole format
Color scenario format, bloody warm red you know the drill!
Monster scenario to tie it all together without all that ordering from a Chinese restaurant menu > they were there, you plop them down and get rolling!
AFV Cards for all the AFVs in the module

—description from the publisher

name.value: Dice Throne: Season Two – Vampire Lord v. Seraph

item.description:
Dice Throne is a game of intriguing dice, tactical card play, powerful heroes, and unique abilities.

It's a fast-paced 2-6 player combat game (1v1, 2v2, 3v3, 2v2v2, or free-for-all). Select from a variety of heroes that play and feel completely distinct from one another. Attack opponents and activate abilities by rolling your hero's unique set of five dice. Accumulate combat points and spend them on cards that have a large range of effects, such as granting permanent hero upgrades, applying status effects, and manipulating dice directly (yours, your teammate's, or even your opponent's).

Dice Throne: Season Two introduces a roster of new heroes and intriguing new matchups.

A stand alone game supporting 2 players. Additional heroes required to play with more than 2 players.

link.value: Dice Throne: Season Two – Cursed Pirate v. Artificer
Dice Throne: Season Two – Gunslinger v. Samurai
Dice Throne: Season Two – Tactician v. Huntress

item.description:
STRUGGLE FOR EUROPE 1939-1945 is a fast-paced, light, two-player, card-driven strategy wargame set in Europe during World War II that allows you to re-fight the entire struggle for Europe at a strategic level in under two hours.

The game starts in 1939 with the Axis player poised to expand rapidly against the Allies (the Polish, French, and British).

Which way to go and who to attack are the early decisions. Can they capture enough to win the game before the first reshuffle.
Game play uses point-to-point movement and area control, hidden army strengths, and decks of cards providing the command choices; there are no dice. The Axis and Allied players each have their own card decks, reflecting the relative strengths and weaknesses of both sides. Each player will have the chance to be the aggressor and defender trying to win the game by the time they have cycled through their card deck for the last time. Victory is achieved by having accumulated the required amount of victory points by capturing victory locations.

As the decks are cycled, the Allied player adds some better quality cards, with the Russians and Americans entering play during the 1st and 2nd reshuffle. The Axis player adds will burn through his early game quality cards, becoming weaker as his resources dwindle. The underlying game mechanism is one of "deck destruction" rather than the more normal deck-building.

Cards have multiple uses and can be recycled if used one way but during the course of the game you have to decide which cards are going to be permanently sacrificed from your deck cycle to allow you to build units.

Game Components:
Mounted Game Board
2 - Decks of 60+ cards
3/4" counters
Rules 
Box

-description from designer

Llama Drama is a family weight card game where players are trying to shed their hand. The base deck allows for 2-4 players, and combining two decks allows for up to 8 players.

Setup:
Deal each player three cards face-down, three cards face-up, and five cards for their hand. Leave the remaining cards face-down as the Draw Pile. Leave some space on the table for a Play Pile and a Discard Pile.

How To Win:
The first player to get rid of all their cards wins!

How To Play:

SETUP
Deal each player three cards face-down, three cards face-up, and five cards for their hand. Leave the remaining cards face-down as the Draw Pile. Leave some space on the table for a Play Pile and a Discard Pile.

HOW TO WIN
The first player to get rid of all their cards wins!

HOW TO PLAY
Choose a player to go first and rotate clockwise. They can play any card to start the Play Pile.

On each turn, you must match or beat the top card of the Play Pile. You may play more than one of the same number or face card on your turn. Higher numbered cards beat lower numbered cards. Special Llama cards have their own rules. You can find these rules on the cards themselves or on the Llama Hierarchy instruction card.

If four cards of the same number or face are played in a row (either in one turn or over consecutive turns), the Play Pile is discarded and the last player plays again. When the Play Pile is empty, a player can play any card to restart the Play Pile.

At the end of a turn, if you have fewer than five cards, draw cards from the Draw Pile to have five in your hand. If on your turn you can't play a card, pick up the Play Pile (yes, the entire Play Pile) and add it to your hand, ending your turn.

Special Rule:
Four cards of the same value played in a row discards the current play pile from the game.

Game End:
Once the Draw Pile runs out, your objective is to get rid of all of your cards. Once your hand is empty, you must play your face-up cards. If none are playable, choose one, and add it to the Play Pile. This pile will become your brand new hand! Yes, you have a hand again. Aren’t llamas fun?

If you pick up cards, you must finish the cards in your hand before you can play your face-up cards again. Once you play all your face-up cards, you must attempt to play your face-down cards, without looking at them. If the card you flip fails, you must pick up the Play Pile with that card, ending your turn. You must once again finish the cards in your hand before you can play your face-down cards again.

The first player to finish all of their cards wins!

Card Types:
Numbered Llamas - Numbered Llamas can be played on themselves, lower number llama cards and some special llama cards.

Baby Llama - The Baby Llama can be played on any card. The next player can then play any card.

Shy Llama - Shy Llama can be played on any card other than Big Llama. The next player can then only play Numbered Llama cards 1-4 or other special llama cards other than Big Llama.

Big Llama - Big Llama can be played on any card other than Shy Llama. The next player can then only play other special llama cards other than Shy Llama.

Magic Llama - Magic Llama can be played on any card. It discards the play pile and allows the player to play a second card, thus starting a new play pile with any card.

Ghost Llama - Ghost Llama can be played on any card. It is invisible and acts like the previous card.

Rachmistrz (Reckoner) is a lightweight math game with a real-time twist. During a turn 3 dice with numbers are rolled and players start to calculate their best move! All players use addition, subtraction, multiplication and division to reach one of numbers available on the main board. They place their tokens on the result of their operations. They have to be fast as once covered, numbers on the board become unavailable for the rest of the game! At the end of the game, the player with most connected tokens is declared the winner. Once you have mastered the regular board with whole numbers try the flip side of the board presenting you with fractions!

Pitch and Yaw is a tabletop miniatures skirmish game, requiring around 6-16 models representing a high seas boarding action in the golden age of piracy. It is a free to download PDF with an extended edition available on our website. 
The game is highly asymmetrical with each player taking turns playing as attacker and defender. The attacker must search the ship before the defender can take too much toll on their forces. Unlike many pirate based skirmish games Pitch and Yaw features a highly dynamic environment representing the difficulty of fighting on a constantly shifting deck. After each round of activating models to move and attack the ship and all unsecured objects will shift.

The old Mayor fell between the gears of Steamopolis. Now we need to elect a new one. Of course this can only be someone who knows how to deal with steampower.

You feel that you have the guts to run the city, but so do your opponents, too. Now it is time to prove your talent.

Steamopolis is a huge steampunk city built like a giant skyscraper of gears and pipes. Different levels provide different services and ressources. To reach them, players use their steam driven zeppelins. They plot their courses, heat up the boilers and then take action.

Steamopolis is an engine building game for 1-4 Players with a fair amount of non destructive interaction. Optimize your engine, utilize it and max it to proof your worth as the future mayor!

—description from the publisher

Double-seven binary-coding hexdominoes is a dominoes-like set that includes 36 tiles (with numbers from 0 to 7) composed of two adjacent hexagons. Instead of the standard ‘pips’, this set uses a special concentric binary representation. A central pip equals 1, a small circle equals 2 and a big circle equals 4. This set is the brother of the Double-seven binary-coding dominoes set by the same publisher:

https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgameversion/280544/nestorgames-edition

The tiles are made of 8mm thick laser-cut, engraved and painted black acrylic.

It's been devised as a game system. Apart from any dominoes game, you can also play Hexdominimum, Hexdominomega, Hexdominup and Hextra, among others.

—description from the publisher

Same thing as L'osti d'jeu, but with 406 new cards (150 black +256 red). It also include 80 blank card so you can make your own extension! Now with black card with double |...| and with asked references of movie, series and other Québec reference!

—description from the publisher (translated)

Le même jeu, mais avec 406 nouvelles cartes (150 noires + 256 rouges) + 80 cartes vierges pour créer ta propre extension! Ça inclut des cartes noires doubles |…| |…|, un plus grand ratio de cartes noires et plein de références québécoises, de télé & films que vous nous avez demandé.

—description from the publisher

In Zangle!, players must twist, flip, or spin the triangle combinations on two or more cards to make the shape on another card. Use all your cards and be the first to go out.

Zangle! includes three ways to play:

• Speedster: Boost your adrenaline and show your skills as you race to find Zangles. The equalizers create new challenges each round.
• Solitaire: Keep your brain kicking and your heart ticking with endless hours of mind-bending fun.
• Turn style: Take your time to find the best Zangle in this casual and conversation-friendly way to play.

64 AD: Rome is burnt to cinders, in need of rebuilding. With the city weakened, distant settlements across the empire refuse to pay taxes and need reminding of power of Rome.
Emperor Nero gathers the most influential members of the city with a clear task: rebuild Rome and recapture the settlements. Each player will utilise their asymmetric abilities to do so and earn wealth along the way in this new, interactive, heavy roll and write game.

Players draft from a pool of custom dice to collect resources and special icons that allow them to build buildings - by drawing onto the map of the Seven Hills of Rome, Tetris-style -, collect legionnaires, invade rogue settlements, or build the famous network of Roman Roads to the already pacified ones. Trading resources and other abilities might earn them coins, building Shrines will allow them to utilise the Favours of the Gods, and careful interaction with other players will surely lead one of them to victory!

—description from the publisher

Every November 2nd in a magical land called Mexico, families build wonderful monoliths decorated with stories and tradition. With their memories, meals and favorite objects altars are decorated in honor of the memory of their loved ones. Today we will build the best of those altars in the city that lives this holiday like no other: Pátzcuaro.

In Pátzcuaro players are responsible for going to a cultural market to get the letters of objects that make up their altars and build them.

From 2 to 4 players, 20 minutes in duration, for 10 years and over, with hand management through cards.

—description from the designer

Who is the Kung Fu champion? Monk Dogs, or Ninja Cats? Come to help them to win the fight!

This is a fast-paced two-player card game. Players take on the role of the Commanders leading the Monk Dogs and the Ninja Cats to fight against each other. During all the rounds of the game, Players assign Animal Cards in their hands into three teams to fight in the three arenas. The winner of each arena is rewarded with new allies, useful items or chance to diminish the opponent's morale (reduce opponent’s SP)! 
Come forward! Use your powers, allies and wits! Do you have what it takes to lead the clan to victory?

-description from designer

å¼±è€…ã®å‰£ (Jakusha no Tsurugi, "Sword of the Weak") is the first game from Polygonotes. It resembles the classic card game Daifugo but adds many twists.

At the start of a round each player is dealt six normal cards and one Sword of the Weak card. Normal cards have two numbers on them, one blue and one red, that always add up to nine, as well as a colored symbol in the middle. The Sword of the Weak has a different pattern on the back and its red and blue numbers are both one.

Your goal is to play all your cards. Each turn you have to either pass (and draw a card) or play cards to the middle. In order to play cards to the middle you have to have a higher total than the previous hand, and whether you use the red or blue numbers depends on the Scales card by the deck - it starts on blue, but every time a Sword of the Weak is played it's flipped. Being lucky will help you play larger hands, but in order to win you'll have to correctly time when you play your Sword card for the greatest advantage.

—user summary

é€†è‡£ã®ç‚Ž (Gyakushin no Honoo, "Flames of the Treacherous Retainer") is the second game from Polygonotes. You play as a servant in the house of a mad king, waiting for a chance to depose him to save the kingdom.

The game has three special kinds of cards. There's one each of the Night and the Dawn, which move around the table - the Night is always held by the active player, and the Dawn by the previous player. In the deck there are many "Flames of the Treacherous Retainer" cards, which have different colored backs. A round ends when one player has three Flames and the Night card; you win by having 20 points at the end of a round.

Each turn you can play a card or draw a card. Some cards can't be played and just add points (positive or negative) to your hand. Others have all kinds of effects, like making another player put a Flame on the bottom of the deck, reversing turn order, or even flipping the deck upside down. Even the Night and Dawn cards are worth points, so you might want to trick someone else into ending the hand.

In order to win you'll have to choose when to play your cards right as well as bluff the other players as to how good your hand is. Can you depose the king?

—user summary

Inspired by the internet's viral challenges that have gathered billions of views, Don't Lose Your Cool tests one's ability to remain calm under pressure. Players wear the Cool-O-Meter that measures their heart rate, and the opposing team rolls the dice that determine how they'll try to get the player to get flustered. A change in heart rate effects the meter and when the meter gets high enough the lights get to red, the alarm sounds, and the opponent wins for making that player lose their composure.

Who will reign supreme in the ultimate snack eating competition? Chow Crown puts a fun twist on viral food-eating challenges! To play, load the six hanging forks with various food items of your choosing. Place the spinning crown on your head, and eat as many snacks as possible before the music stops to keep your crown!

Chow Crown can be played solo or in a head-to-head tournament. The game includes the electronic crown, six plastic forks, and instructions. Requires 3 AA batteries, not included. Food not included.

Awkward Hugs is the game of connections, questions, and consequences! Two players are locked in a hug by the included hug belts, and another player asks questions like, "Would you swim with sharks?" or "Are you a binge watcher?" Both huggers must answer the same way or they'll get a hilarious consequence card such as slow dancing or standing like a flamingo. Match three questions correctly to unlock the hug.

Game includes two hug belts, two keys, a deck of questions cards, a deck of consequences cards, and a game guide.

ä¿¡æ¿ƒå›½åœŸè±ªè¡† (Shinanokoku Dogoushu, "Lords of Shinano") is a card-laying game about exploring mountainous terrain and choosing the right spot to build a castle.

Each turn you may move and add a card to the map. You can move one step across normal terrain, pay two points to move through mountains, or you can move as far as you want along a river for free. When you add a card it has to be on a space next to your pawn and any rivers must line up. You get points equal to the number on the card (1, 2, or 3, with higher point cards being more complicated) for every edge that perfectly matches what you put it against. If no edges match you can still play the card but it's worth negative points equal to its face value. If you can't play a card at all, you have to discard one face down, which is worth triple negative points at the end of the game.

Once during the game you must play a castle. This costs ten points, but at the end of the game you get points for the card under your castle and the four neighboring cards. Castles must be built at least two cards apart, so building in the right place can also deny other players points. When moving, castles and pawns both allow you charge tolls for anyone passing through, which is the best way to get a point advantage over other players.

Explore the countryside, build your castle in the right place, and see if you can become the richest Lord of Shinano.

—user summary

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Have a "blast" and take aim as players "pie" their opponent with a cannon full of whipped cream! To start Pie Face Cannon!, one player steps up and places their face in the facemask, while the other player aims the cannon and tries to launch whipped cream onto their opponent's face. The player behind the mask can try to avoid getting "pie-faced" by using the included blocking hand. Players can earn points by either blocking themselves or by successfully "pie-ing" their opponent. The first player to score five points wins.

Whipped cream not included.

Can you overcome the voice-jamming challenge in Speech Breaker? You're reporting live from the scene! Put on the game headset, talk into the game microphone, and get your teammates to guess who/what/where without saying any of the words on the cards. What's the catch? The microphone jams your speech with a built-in delay. As you talk, you hear your delayed voice through the game headset, making it harder to speak clearly. For example, how would you report that "an alien is swinging kettlebells in a glass house" without saying any of those words — and in just 30 seconds — with your speech jammed?

ç«œå§«ã®å’Ž (Ryuuki no Toga, "The Sin of the Dragon Princess") is a push-your luck engine building game. There are only five days left before the final battle - can you defeat the enemy and become a legendary hero?

Long ago the Dragon Princess broke a taboo and had a child with a human. The "Sin" was a target for all the monsters in the world, and to defend her child the Dragon Princes descended into the Abyss. After an unimaginably long time, the Abyss transformed the Dragon Princess into a monster, and she's coming to reclaim her child and destroy the world in the bargain. You have just five days to defeat her.

Each round has three phases: card acquisition, playing units, and deciding whether to challenge the monster. A number of cards equal to the numbers of players is dealt face-up, and everyone reveals which one they want at the same time. If there are any conflicts, the start player for the round decides how to resolve that, and it doesn't have to be fair. Next you play units that add to your battle strength. Some units can be played for free, but advanced units will require spending mana of right color from weaker units. Finally you decide if you're ready to challenge the monster. You only get to do this once, so you want to wait until you're strong enough, but not so long someone else beats the monster first.

—user summary

Hero is an ATM is a 3~5 small game.
In this game, every player will be a greedy priest, who only want to earn money. We can create monster to fight hero and take their money, treatment hero and ask for reward, or sell useless products to hero.
After 6 rounds, who get the most money will win the game.

—user summary

This game is a hero ability card game. When the game start, everyone picks 3 hero cards as their ability. Each turn, a player can choose two actions to do:

 Draw 3 cards
 Take 2 public cards
 Play 1 card
 Finish 1 goal card
 Cure any units




There are 2 different types of cards:

 Unit card: When you play the unit card, you can use the ability of the unit. The number of the same unit you have determines LV of the ability. After you use the ability, the unit will keep on your board.
 Magic card: Use the ability and discard it.




After your turn, each finished goal card will earn 1 Billion. The player who reaches 50 Billion first will win the game.

—user summary

The Singaporean Dream is a humorous card game that lets you steal, sabo and pay your way to be the perfect Singaporean.

You play a classic Singaporean Personality (different for each player) that grants you special powers.

The game goal is to collect as many dream as you can before the dream pile runs out. You can buy the Dream Cards with Cash Cards in the bank or gain them with Action Cards.

During your turn, you draw two cards and play up to 3 actions:
- play an action card from your hand;
- place money in bank (cards from hand to table)
- buy a dream using money in bank;
- use personality special power.
keep doing this until the dreams runs out.

Core Connection is a deck-building card game for 2-4 players in which you take on the role of a pilot of a Resonant, a giant mecha, fighting to free society from the tyrannical reign of its oppressors! Pilot your Resonant with unique tactics and upgrade it with enhancements to defeat the army of Atlantis!

Rise of Atlantis is the base Core Connection game and comes with everything needed to start playing!

'The Big Easy' is a competitive card game set in alternate history New Orleans. Designed by renowned Deadlands author and creator of Deadlands Noir, John Goff, the Big Easy pits players against each other as private investigators competing to solve a brutal crime.

In The Big Easy, all players play from the same deck of cards as they move around the city in search of a suspect, motive, and a piece of evidence. The first player to come up with all three clues solves the case and wins the game.

At each location they visit, however, the detectives must overcome some obstacle or threat, ranging from organized criminals to diabolical cultists and demons. As if that weren't enough, their rival detectives are always meddling in their investigation, trying to slow them down and steal the vital lead for themselves.

With cunning, guts, and a little luck, you should be able to keep your enemies at bay long enough to crack the case and clean up the streets of The Big Easy.

—description from the publisher

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: On Pointe: The Ballet Board Game

item.description:
Experience life as a ballet dancer, from the Barre to a Star. Earn your pointe shoes and tutu; collect gems, treasures and the tiara.

In On Pointe players use dance moves as shown on the deck of cards to move through the game from the first dance studio through rehearsal and eventually to the stage. Players stop at certain intervals in the game to collect gems, which are worth 3 points and treasures, which are worth 2 points.

Each player has a score card where they accumulate the items for later end-of-game scoring. Points are also awarded for landing on the Pas de Deux squares, the Prima Ballerina square where one player will get the tiara and the final stage square for the bouquet and bow.

In addition to the cards, each player has five 'Position Tokens' each of which can only be used once and then is turned over after executing the given 'power-up' move or action.

The player who is positioned last, in relation to the front edge of the stage gets first selection of movement cards shown on the table and play proceeds clock-wise from there. The result of this turn designation is that players tend to travel though the game board fairly closely together.

Since the winner is determined by a calculation of points, arriving first at the end of the stage does not guarantee a win.

On Pointe is a dancer's journey in a board game.

As a follow-up to Ein Mann. Ein Spiel., Marcel-André Casasola Merkle designed the game Eine Frau. Ein Spiel. based on the book, "Eine Frau. Ein Buch.".

One played reads a question from a deck of question cards, with multiple choice answers, and the quickest player to grab the champagne bottle token will give an answer. The player that is answering can wager an amount of diamonds based upon their confidence, and other players can grab the bottle and provide other answers.

The publisher's website includes the following sample questions:

Which faux pas are you not allowed to commit as a woman during a visit to the Academy Awards? Under what circumstances is a marriage null and void? And why may a convertible in Bavaria not be pushed?

In 500 BC, Ionia rebelled against Persia's rule and Greece supported it. With this "foreign interference" as an excuse, the Persian empire decided to invade Greece. In 492 BC the Persian forces attacked Macedonia from land and sea.

The Persians and the Greeks fought fiercely at Marathon, Thermopylae, and Salamis. Against the overwhelming forces of the Persian empire, the Greeks used superior tactics and "weapons" such as hoplites (heavy infantry) and triremes. The Greeks had also excellent leaders in times of crises and eventually prevailed over the Persians.

300: Greco-Persian Wars is a wargame for two players. One player controls the Greeks, gathered around the Athenians, and the other controls the Persians, fighting for the hegemony of the eastern Mediterranean. Through all five expeditions, each player aims to control more cities than his opponent.

The game engine is a "card driven" system. Players raise armies and buy cards during production. Cards can be used to play an event or move an army or fleet. Events can provide advantages in battles or interfere with the enemy, but military action is paramount to win. Moreover, each game will change dramatically according the order the events occur.

The rules are simple and the playing time is short, but both Greece and Persia have a wide range of strategies, so victory will challenge both players.

The game contains only Japanese rules and the events on the cards are in Japanese.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Yuzu? is a game of words, knowing, bluff and a little chance.
It's like the "Scrabbles" had met "6 Takes" !
You play cards with letters to build words.
But if the cards you have in hand doesn't make any valid word, your last solution is to bluff everyone pretending it exists...

Moogic is a strategy card game capturing the thrill of competitive cattle farming. Building and running an economically viable farm will require the skillful management of resources as well as the strategic deployment and timely slaughter of cattle for income. Along the way you will also raise revenue by milking your cows, breeding cattle and sending your herd to graze on both your own and your opponent's farm, all while attempting to defend your own patch of grass from your similarly inclined neighbor.

Players have a hand of cards from which they play farmland, cattle, action, enrichment, and building cards. Farmland cards are free to play and produce grass which can be spent to play other cards. Any unspent grass can be grazed on by your opponent's cattle to earn money. Money can also be earned by milking cows or slaughtering cattle. Action and enrichment cards directly affect the player or other cards in play. The winner is the first player to earn 100 coins.

-description from designer

Six empires have risen from the ashes of the Galactic Realm. Still cemented by the alliance that enabled their unprecedented conquest of the galaxy, the six independent kingdoms now seek to consolidate their power, each hoping to carve out the strongest dominion in the cosmos. Conflicts among the young realms are inevitable, but will the galaxy return to a state of civil war?

Core Worlds: Empires is a worker placement game for 2-6 players. Each world in the galaxy occupies a board space that ambassadors (workers) can visit during the game. The worlds that appear during each game are variable. Each player starts with a certain number of worlds under their control, and more worlds enter the game as play proceeds.

At the start of the game, each player controls one unique worker that represents their faction leader (Chancellor Augustus, Baron Viktor, Prince Aaron, Empress Elona, Simon the Fox, or Lord Banner), as well as three generic ambassadors. All players periodically receive new generic ambassadors, but each player always possesses the same number of "workers". Players may upgrade their generic ambassadors into unique heroes in order to increase the quality of their individual workers.

A game for unicorn lovers. A magical game of unicorns that is simple and fun for all. Get the most unicards by matching mane color, hoof color, and horn color to the unicard you wish.

Players have a hand of 5 cards. Most cards have a unicorn on them with a colored mane, hooves, or horn in one of the 7 colors of the rainbow. Cards are also marked with a shape to help differentiate colors and for help with the colorblind.

During a turn, a player draws a card from the top of the deck or the discard pile. Once a player has three matching color unicorn cards of all three types (hooves, horn, and mane) they may discard all three and claim that color Unicard.

Unicards are separate from the cards used in the deck and player hands. There are 7 Unicards, one for each of the colors of the rainbow, and the first player to claim 4 Unicards wins the game. But be careful, because other players can steal your UniCards by also matching the same colors.

Also included are rainbow unicorns that can be used as any color and the dark horse which prevents you from winning.

—user summary

Kids game, in which you try to roll sets of the same pictures by rolling 5 dice (for 3, 4 or 5 tokens), or roll 5 different pictures (for 7 tokens).
The first to fill up his card with 25 tokens wins the game.

—user summary

ãã®ã„ã¡ã«ã¡ã‹ã„ (Kunoichi ni Chikai) is a game about ninjas in training. A "kunoichi" is a female ninja, and "kunoichi ni chikai" means "almost a kunoichi" - but you could also read it as "close to the ku". But what's "ku"? It's a little pink token in the box! Use the powers of your kunoichi trainees to move them around in the grid and get closer to the "ku"!

At the start of the game sixteen cards, one for each character, are laid out in a four by four grid. The players are dealt an equal number of cards, each corresponding to one of the ninjas. Each card has a different ability to move cards around, like "swap any card and the one two to the right and one down from it" or "slide any column up, wrapping around". After each player has used all but one of their cards, the last card determines which ninja they get points for, with more points going to ninjas closer to the "ku".

In order to win you'll have to use your powers to rearrange the grid while balancing that with holding on a character in a good position, even if they have good powers. You also have to be careful not to favor any character too obviously as other players can interrupt your plans.

Can you get close to the "ku" and finally become a full kunoichi?

—user summary

item.description:
Malkyrs: Arenas of Eternity is a collectible card game, with elements of role-playing and timing allowed by the use of computers/phones and wireless technology.

Each card contains a RFID chip, which is recognized either by a proprietary reader or a smartphone app, and allows it to keep track of :

 its current Health, Might, Intelligence and Strength levels ;
 its learned Skills ;
 its Evolutions (by using "Favor" points) ;




which means that, two physically identical cards can be different in-game depending on their players record.

The game itself centers around the idea of a main Champion card, which embodies the player as it casts Action cards to bring its oppenent's Health total to 0.
Playing these Actions has an element of timing, as a computer app keeps tracks of player turns, which last by default 30 seconds ; some effects can alter this total, or some cards have different effects depending on how soon/late they have been cast.

Each victory grants Glory points, which are tracked by the app, and can be reinvested as Favor points to upgrade cards (see above). The app also allows to play online.

Do you believe psychics can glimpse into the future or that all psychics are frauds? The mystical and hysterical game of Trust Me, I'm Psychic might change your thinking!

In this unpredictable game of predictions, one player acts as the Customer, asking a question about their future that the Psychics must answer. All other players act as Psychics, and are dealt a Vision card that tells them if they are a true Psychic or a Fraud. All the players who are true Psychics see the same tarot-inspired image that they can use to craft a fortune for the customer. The Frauds do not see the picture, and will just have to wing it (with some help from the Cursed Words clues on their card)!

The Customer asks a question on any subject about his or her future. Will I win the lottery? Will I find true love this year? Whether you are a Psychic or a Fraud, use your imagination to spin a fantastical fortune for the Customer. Of course, fortune-telling is not as easy as it seems. Psychics and Frauds must avoid speaking the forbidden Cursed Words listed at the bottom of their cards. If your fellow Psychics/Frauds catch you saying a Cursed Word, you'll get a Curse Token.

If you tell a convincing fortune the Customer rewards you with a token and gets to look at your card. If the Customer chose a true Psychic, they can use the image on the card to deduce who the remaining Psychics are. But if the Customer accidentally pays a Fraud, he or she gets a Curse Token.

The game ends after each player has a turn being the Customer. The player with the most money tokens (after subtracting Curse Tokens)wins!

—description from the publisher

item.description: It seems simple: Lay 4 squares in a row while preventing the others to lay their 4 squares in a row before you.

You are an air-shipwright, that is, an inventor of flying machines used by the dreams to traverse the skies of the Oniverse. You have been challenged to build a new fleet, the most beautiful ever seen. Now you must roll the dice to acquire the components you need to build airships.

In Aerion, a solo/co-operative game for 1-2 players, you must find the best blueprints, acquire the finest construction materials, and recruit the best crew. Discarding cards can adjust your die rolls, but be careful not to exhaust your resources! Can you build the best fleet?

Aerion includes six expansion modules with new options and challenges.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Se Rappeler, also known as "Fun to Remember" is a box containing the components to play a series of children's memory games:


 The Pairs Memory Game - the traditional "Memory" game where players turn over two cards at a time trying to make matched pairs.



 The Countryside Game - On a board depicting an outdoor scene, a player arranges several pieces in the empty spaces and shows it to the other player. The first player then secretly changes one or two pieces and shows it again to the other player, who must identify the changes. Players take turns until one has identified ten changes correctly.



 Kim's Game - Players take turns being the dealer. They place 20 silhouette pictures on the table, give other players a few seconds to look and then secretly remove one or more. Players then must mark on their board which pieces have been removed, keeping the markers for correct guesses. After each player has been dealer twice, the player with the most markers wins. 



 What Followed Next? - Players start with a set of eight pictures face-down. The first player chooses a picture, looks at it, says aloud what it is and then places it face-down, starting a row. The second player chooses a second tile, looks and then must say the name of the first and second tiles in order. The third player must name the first two tiles in order and then his or her newly-drawn tile. This continues until a player thinks another has made a mistake and calls for a check. The tiles are checked and whichever player is wrong is eliminated. Play includes until only one player remains.



 In the Pocket Game - Each player has a board depicting 20 objects. Silhouette tiles of these objects form a supply. In turn, each player chooses a silhouette and hides it. The player to the left then asks a yes/no question about the item (e.g. "is it round?"). If the answer is no, the next player asks a question. If the answer is yes, the asker may guess the identity of the item. If correct, the player receives the tile and places it in the correct space on his or her board. If incorrect, the next player may take a turn. The player who wins the tile becomes the next to choose a tile and answer questions. The first player to get five tiles wins.


—user summary

Discover the Salem Area is a Monopoly clone where the properties represent businesses and organizations in the town of Salem, Ohio.

—user summary

Tactical board game full of bluff and manipulation

In Carnavalo you are a carnival leader who tries to earn as many feathers as possible at the different party locations. To get the majority in one location, you play covered cards. Meanwhile, you have to dodge Prince Carnival, who is doing his best to recruit people for his less popular parade. Miss Carnavalo and Barricadol are the other characters who manipulate the parties in the city.

At the end of a round you win feathers if you have the majority in one location and you lose them if you have the most people in the parade. The player who bluffs and manipulates the best wins the game and will enjoy the carnival most.

Carnavalo is a tactical board game with no luck factors. The only unknown elements are the secret actions of the other players, creating chaotic and surprising situations.

—description from the publisher (translated)

item.description:
æ„šè€…ã®æ£º (Gusha no Hitsugi, "Fool's Casket") is a test-your-luck game from Polygonotes. A band of heroes have found an ancient treasure horde, but before they can take any of the prizes away they'll have to get by the ghosts that haunt it.

Each round you'll try to get a piece of treasure by drawing from the ghost deck. If you draw a ghost with the same element as the treasure you can keep it, but if the fourth ghost of a type comes out it'll play a trick. Exactly what the trick does varies by type, but it includes swapping your treasure with the top of the deck, swapping someone else's treasure, or even flipping the deck upside down.

You can choose what treasure you go after, so will you go for high points, the safe bet, or try to interfere with the other players? You can avoid ghost types that are about to play a trick on you, or you can go after them to trigger the trick on purpose.

The first player to ten points wins the round and escapes the tomb with their treasure - and their life!

—user summary

å‹‡å£«ã®æ¥” (Yuushi no Kusabi, "Bonds of the Brave") is about heroes deciding which army to join. You want to be the strongest member of the winning army, but you'll have to find out what the other players are planning while hiding your own intentions.

At the start players are dealt three cards, and four cards are dealt to the middle, two face up and two face down. Each turn you take cards from the middle, put some from your hand back, and then add more cards to the middle from the deck. Once someone has ten points in one color they can announce victory for that team; everyone else gets one chance to announce victory for another color if they also have ten points, and then you move on to scoring. Declaring victory in a color is advantageous but might not be enough to overcome a sneaky player; whoever has the most points total over all victorious colors wins the round. This means that besides winning on the strength of your own hand, you can win by investing in multiple suits other people are stronger in.

The most subtle part of the game is the different kinds of cards. While some cards give a simple color bonus, those are the rarest. The next most common type can count for either of two colors during scoring, but don't count towards the 10 for declaring victory. Most cards are worth few points on their own, but worth more in pairs with specific cards - in particular, the purple color has no invidually strong cards, but is worth the most with the right pair. Each color has its own distribution, and keeping that in mind is key to victory.

Can you read the other players to figure out which color you should throw your lot in with?

—user summary

æ˜Ÿç«œã®å†  (Seiryuu no Kanmuri, "Crown of the Star Dragon") is the third game from Polygonotes. You play adventurers chasing after the precious scales of the Star Dragon; the game is semi-cooperative, with a pure coop mode for 2-3 players and a more competitive mode with the potential for betrayal for 3-4 players.

Each turn has three phases. In the preparation phase, you can spend Stars to buy items or heal, and you choose an item to use in the combat phase. In the combat phase, you flip a card from the Star Dragon deck and resolve its attack. Only the players with the highest attack or defense rating take part in combat. If things go well you can earn Stars here, but if they poorly some players will take damage. Some Dragon cards also have special effects like doing damage to players with too many Stars. Finally, in the Spoils phase the Stars earned in combat are split evenly among all participants. The game ends after ten turns, when the Dragon's Crown is revealed.

Because Stars are used to heal damage as well as to buy the items you attack with every turn, you'll have to balance offense and defence in order to survive the dragon's attacks. If you're playing to win you can play it safe in a round by trying to avoid combat... but since you won't get a share of the spoils that's risky too. You'll need balance in how you deal with the Dragon as well as your allies to come out ahead.

—user summary

Area 1851: Express combines card drafting and set collection in the Wild West, where aliens have landed and are trading technology with the local natives and settlers to create out-of-this-world gadgets with comical modifications that are sure to bring lots of laughter to your game night.

During the game, each player will spend three rounds drafting cards to build and modify gadgets. Doing so will provide them with Reputation (points) as well as various bonuses ranging from extra Reputation up to tokens that provide special abilities on later turns.

At the end of three rounds, the player that has managed to earn the highest reputation wins.

-description from designer

item.description:
The little monkey Banane Joe is taking a nap on its banana palm. Try to take away as much bananas as possible from him to win the game. In each round you roll the dice - to make the game more interesting, you may have to give another player one of your bananas without warning or you are allowed to take one banana from one of the others. But take care of Banana Joe! If you have taken too many bananas from his banana palm, he is going to jump into the air. Try to catch him to get additional bananas.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Matschbirne is a game where the players have to use their full body to prove your drawing skills. Each of you can play on its own or you can create teams. One of the players takes a card and has to draw the term written on it. You are not allowed to use your hands for it - aggravated circumstances.

The one drawing applies the headband with the pencil attached to it. Now you have to draw with skilful head movements. This is of course harder than expected - and will lead to lots of laughter!

—description from the publisher (translated)

A fun family friendly game for 4-8 players, ages 10 and up.
It’s Christmas Eve, and you’ve all forgotten to get each other gifts! Now you’ve got a few hours left before the store closes to rush and get some gifts that (hopefully) match each other’s interests and score some points. The most points at the end of the game wins. Just watch out for people being Naughty!

Everyone gets 3 unique interest cards at the start of the game, as well as some fit cards to get started. Each gift has two interest on it, including a few double interest cards, ad each round, players will have to give out a gift. Each match is worth 2 points, and a self match is 1 point.

And then there are Naughty or Nice cards. Naughty cards to things like steal cards and swap gifts, while Nice cards help out the other players, but score 1 point. There are also Block cards, which will stop the other Naughty and Nice cards, and can score points if used to block Naughty cards.

—description from the publisher

Party game in which a group of players secretely pick a spell, which influences the way they can answer questions from the one player trying to guess what spell they have picked. By asking up to 3 rounds of questions, deduction is used to find out the mysterious spell.

—user summary

Et sans résultat! is a grand tactical wargaming for the Napoleonic period.

The grand tactical focus means that a lot of low-level detail is abstracted away, a battalion being represented by a single stand. While this loss of detail may be mourned by some, it allows battles to be fought in a timely manner and players to concentrate on the tasks of generals rahter than of junior officers.

The rules aim to be compatible with figures from 2mm to 28mm size, and almost any basing scheme. There are also boxed sets of 10mm figures from The Wargaming Company purpose-made for the rules for those who don't already have an Napoleonics collection.

The title, French for "And without result!", is from Marshal Ney's comment on the indecisive yet bloody battle of Eylau.

An expansion for Verdammt Nochmal or on its own. This version provides much more really bad situations and you have to decide whether "You skate into a drain" or "The cash machine withdraws your card". Everything gets rated based on a "misery index". If you are correct, you can keep the card, otherwise its the turn of the next player. Arrange 10 cards correctly to win the game.

—description from the publisher (translated)

name.value: Verdammt Nochmal: 50 Shades of Shit Edition

item.description:
An expansion for Verdammt Nochmal or on its own. This version provides much more really bad situations and you have to decide whether "You see your father being naked" or "Your phone falls into the toilet". Everything gets rated based on a "misery index". If you are correct, you can keep the card, otherwise its the turn of the next player. Arrange 10 cards correctly to win the game.

—description from the publisher (translated)

A strategy game for 2-4 people. Cell-O allows players to change their pieces over the course of the game, creating countless combinations of movement possibilities!

In Cell-O, each player starts with a single cell creature which can move, eat, multiply and evolve into slowly-growing shapes that dictate their future movement. Competing against other creatures for food and space, players must try and expand their population enough to escape the primordial pool of their species' birth into the greater world beyond.

During a turn, each player gets one action to move, eat, or spawn a new creature from an existing one. Eating gives a creature a new shape that then dictates how it moves in future. It takes tactics and foresight to mutate and expand your population in order to escape while preventing your opponent's from doing the same.

When a player gets enough of their creatures across the board and out of the pool, they win!

-description from designer

Storm of Spears is a set of grand-tactical miniatures wargames rules for Greek hoplite battles of the late fifth and early fourth centuries BC. They also cover contemporary Rome, Etruria, and Carthage.

Despite the grand-tactical scope, the rules allow players to control quite a bit of tactical detail like file spacing and line depth, these being deemed critical to the tactics of the period.

Scenarios are provided for seven historical battles (all Greek), and orders of battle are provided for dozens of further battles and campaigns. The rules allow for troops based on 30, 40, or 60mm frontages.

—user summary

Port GdaÅ„sk has never been so busy! Tens of vessels are calling at the quays, while long arms of port cranes are put in motion high above the ground. Another busy day is starting in the largest Polish port. Dockworkers have their hands full to unload the goods waiting on vessels as fast as possible.

In Port GdaÅ„sk board game you act as a company operating in the Port. Your task is to load and unload goods to make them reach their warehouses or means of transport in the shortest time. Don’t forget about hiring workers and serving the awaiting cruise ships. It’s thanks to them that you’ll gain an advantage over your competition that’s breathing down your neck and you’ll increase your chances of winning. Be fast, first vessels are already calling at the quays!

The game Port GdaÅ„sk consists of a series of player’s turns. In your turn, you roll the dice to determine what kinds of actions you can perform. Available actions: loading, movement, and recruitment. Before or after performing the actions from the dice roll, you can do some additional activities:

 Execute one order,
 Use exchange panel once,
 Serve one cruise ship.




Gather goods, fill in port warehouses executing precious orders and send off your workers to serve the cruise ships!

—description from the designer

A fun and simple matching game for children aged 2-6. Turn over welly cards to find matching pairs of wellies for your monsters. The first player to fill their board wins!

There are two ways to play this colourful game, for both younger and more advanced players. This means children of all ages can play and enjoy the game together, either as a simple pairs matching or more complex memory game. The patterned welly cards can also be used to encourage children to identify the objects they can see on them.

Featuring an array of colourful character illustrations, the quirky monsters are bound to get children giggling!

The sun is setting on one of the most devastating battles the Pocket Universe has ever seen. After years of fighting, it is becoming clear that this war will not be won on the strength of military victories alone. The leaders of the Dynasty and the Liberation turn their attention to some of the most influential figures in the galaxy to strengthen their cause. Who will be able to consolidate their power, gain new allies, and turn old foes to their side? Who can form a Conclave powerful enough to gain control of the Universe?

Anthelion is a game for 2 players who choose two unique special character abilities on their turn to manipulate the locations of the characters in play. Players seek to pull characters from all factions, good, evil and neutral to their side of the table (their Conclave), or push unwanted characters to their opponent. The player that can amass ten points of influence by getting enough characters to cross all the way to their side of the table will be declared the winner.

link.value: Guild: Game Designers of North Carolina

item.description:
The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a d8 die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept, and the person with the most cards after 10 minutes is the winner.

This version is designed for the Hungarian market, but is completely in English. In fact, practicing English skills is noted as another benefit of playing the game.

—user summary

A BrainBox Hungary angolul nem csak a hazánkról szerzett ismereteket bÅ‘víti, de az angoltudást is játékosan fejleszti!
Jegyezz meg minél több információt 10 másodperc alatt a kihúzott kártyán szereplÅ‘ hazai nevezetességekrÅ‘l, majd dobj a kockával és válaszolj helyesen a kidobott szám szerinti kérdésre, persze angolul! De ne húzd az idÅ‘t, mert a homokórán gyorsan leszaladnak a szemek! A helyes válaszokat a kártyán ellenÅ‘rizheted. Ha jó megfigyelÅ‘ vagy, akkor a legtöbb kártya nálad landol!

—description from the publisher

Die Fly! is a 2-6 player card game where each player will take their turn by playing a card onto one of two discard piles. Most of the cards in the deck are flies. When a discard pile has some flies in it any player out of turn can play a fly swatter card. When playing a fly swatter card on one of the discard piles that player then collects all of the cards in that piles. The more flies you kill the more points you are awarded at the end. There are other cards that allow you to steal from another player hand or from another players kill pile (the bug zapper, and frog cards). The spider allows you to kill two flies directly out of your hand. The food cards allows you to name a type of fly and any player that has that type in their hand must give you all of those flies. You can't forget the poop card when played forces the opponents to place a fly directly on it, but also when someone uses a fly swatter card on a pile that has a poop card that player must complete a penalty to continue on the game.

The theme is based off of flies, butterflies, and dragonflies. The art is goofy but totally fits with the style of play. It is a fun family friendly game that only takes about 15 minutes to play.

—description from the publisher
Promotional pack of 55 cards (including rules) included as a gift in the December delivery of the "Le Petit Ballon" wine subscription box.

Herd: Fleece Your Friends is a competitive card game where luck and skill are equal partners on the path to victory. So, grab your crook and let's go! In Herd, you are obsessed with one thing: creating the greatest herds in the land. Score points by acquiring geep, a half-goat half-sheep hybrid, and organizing them into herds. Protect your herds from marauding wolves, but if a wolf emerges from the hills you can send it to devour the herd of another player.

Players are dealt a hand of three cards to start the game. During their turn, players begin by drawing a card from the draw pile. Four options are then available: Form a herd, play a wolf on another player's herd, play a specialty card, or allow the next player to go. A player scores points by forming herds using three geep cards of the appropriate colors. Herd: Fleece your Friends is played in rounds. A round ends after one of the players plays her last card and has nothing else in her hand. Other players have one final turn. At the end of the round, the point values of the player's herds are totaled and the point value of the cards remaining in the player's hand are subtracted from this total. This is the player's score for the round. The player with the highest total wins a victory token. The first player to collect three victory tokens is the winner of the game!

—description from the publisher

Based on the movie with same name.

In this co-op game local businesman want to cut off all the forest. Players must find evidence that there are living great grey owl in this forest. The species belong to red list so it is only hope to save the beautiful forest.

Players roll the dice, move their characters and collect the evidence-cards. Also the businessman move in the forest and try to remove the evidences. If any player collects the 5 different evidence cards in front of him/her before the deck is exhausted all player win. Otherwise they lose.

—user summary

Red Out is a rock-paper-scissors like game where each player has only five cards: black, white, black skull, white skull, and red skull.

The red skull beats the other skulls. The skulls beat the same color without a skull. Any other combination is a draw. Players reveal cards at the same time, putting aside any cards in a drawn match, until someone wins.

Because draws are common, this is more than just RPS with a different skin - it adds an element of keeping track of what your opponent has left to play.

—user summary
